the stars were beginning to twinkle in the sky
unexpected visitor arrived just as dinner was being served
the ancient ruins echoed with the sound of footsteps
everyone held their breath, waiting for the results
the detective noticed something odd about the crime scene
the dog barked loudly, alerting the entire neighborhood
she realized the painting was actually a hidden map
the wind whispered secrets through the broken window panes
the elevator stopped between floors, trapping them inside
the final note of the song lingered in silence
just beyond the ridge where no one dared to go
the taste of copper still on his tongue
before the sun could rise over the distant hills
closer than they had expected, almost touching the edge
without looking back or slowing her pace
because the signal had disappeared without explanation
until everything collapsed into a quiet stillness
after the last train had already left the station
barely enough time to react before it was gone
as if the sky itself had started to bleed
somewhere beneath the rubble, something began to move
the weight of silence heavier than before
before anyone realized what it actually meant
a faint light blinking through the dust and smoke
not sure if it was real or imagined
hands shaking, breath shallow, unable to speak
what remained of the photograph in her pocket
the words scratched into the wall behind the curtain
a whisper that wasn’t carried by the wind
when the clock froze at exactly three seventeen
left unfinished like a story missing its last page
underneath the floorboards where no one had looked
a message too garbled to fully understand
still echoing from the last time they spoke
no one noticed the shadow leave the room
right before the power cut out completely
waiting for an answer that never came
a scent that reminded him of childhood summers
too late to stop what had already started
just as the signal began to fade again
something scratching just beyond the wooden door
the color drained from her face instantly
left open with the wind howling through it
flickering lights revealing shapes that didn’t belong
pressed between the pages of a forgotten journal
he turned to speak but no words came
without warning, the floor gave way beneath them
more questions than answers with every passing minute
a single red thread tied around the handle
faint footsteps in the hallway, growing louder
and then everything went quiet again
